title: Wall mount for cheap Belkin power bar.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I picked up a couple of cheap power bars on sale.  When I got home I realized they had no mounting hardware.  This model corrects this issue.

Print using your usual settings.  If you are planning on having heavy wall warts on it, print it with 30% or more infill.
Find a screw that fits well (I found a #8 head sat flush inside), screw it in, then just drop your cheap Belkin power bar in.
Changed to more restrictive license due to Makerbot legal changes.  Sorry!

comments.text: Is this for an ordinary power bar like those in canada?
comments.author: birdbatoune

author: futurejames

description.text: Old logo of software Maya.

remixed_from.author: keff
remixed_from.title: Keff's Weeping Skeleton Vampire Mummy Earphone Winder

remixed_from.author: EvoGenius
remixed_from.title: Weeping Skeleton Vampire Mummy Earphone Winder Bottle Opener

description.text: This is version 2 of my remixed Weeping Skeleton Vampire Mummy bottle opener/earbud winder. I have thickened it up a bit as well as added slots for the earbud wire. The file is in STL format. Hope you like it and happy printing!!

i recommend printing with 100% infill and adding the penny mid-print. if you have a heated bed i suggest leaving the penny on an out-of-the-way corner of the plate and using pliers to handle the penny as it will be HOT! be careful!!

So i have been dreaming of this design for a while, but certain parts are still left to conquer. Hopefully someone out there can help. I have provided the OpenSCAD model in order to speed things up. Its \"parameterized\" so you simply change variable values and you get a whole new container! The concept here is that the object is printed with the right size and spec to your phone. You then cut and sew together an elastic band. Let it be known that i do not have any real prior experience with sewing, so if i can do it, you can too. :) Potential Future Mods: Round mounting profile so its more comfortable to wear, walls that curve in to lock in phone, completely sealed case to protect from rain and spills. I look forward to seeing other peoples ideas! Click to see an album of the print and other detailed images:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/cidvilas/sets/72157623863202831/

Step 1: Print the provided file with your favorite 3D printer.
  • Be sure to set your phones dimensions to truly customize your design. Also note that you are able to set the width of the elastic band used.
    • Step 2: Cut and an elastic band to your biceps length. If you choose to mount this somewhere else, then cut to length necessary. I used some, not so sticky, velcro. Find some very sticky velcro to prevent this from undoing and falling off your arm! Then simply string the elastic band through the printed object and mount.

comments.text: Mobile Arduino arm band??
comments.author: 2ROBOTGUY

comments.text: Great idea!  You can also make a case that will mount an Arduino!  What would you do with it then?
comments.author: 2ROBOTGUY

title: Flower Planter or Beer Torpedo!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Short version: This is a planter.  It looks like it would look nice with a flower in it.
Long version: So my friend and I were floating in the pool, with no convenient place to rest our beer.  Afterwards we got cracking on the issue.  Unfortunately alcohol does not lend itself well to design work and our measurements were all wrong.  So our object couldn't hold beer cans.  We field tested (pool tested?) it with a beer bottle and we found it shot to the bottom even faster; apparently the cones we added didn't help buoyancy but they definitely made it more hydrodynamic!  So while it was a dismal failure as a beer floater, it works well as a planter.
Its also an excellent beer torpedo, in case you were ever in a beer bottle race to the bottom of the pool**.
** I do not condone playing with glass in the pool.  In fact, you shouldn't be playing with glass at all when you're drinking.  Or OpenSCAD for that matter. :D

Print it.
Put dirt in it.
Stick a plant in it.
Definitely do not play with glass. Changed to more restrictive license due to Makerbot legal changes. Sorry!

author: futurejames

description.text: Here is my rendition of the Transformer's Decepticon Emblem/Logo. It was modeled in Solidworks. I have provided the STL and Solidworks Part File for your enjoyment. Have fun!
Print it any which way you like!

title: Makerbot Replicator 2 Out Of Filament detector

description.text:
This is an Out of Filament detector for the Makerbot Replicator 2 with Sailfish firmware installed. It uses the p-stop option that is only available when using sailfish firmware. Please read the following links before attempting.
Switch used is a simple OMRON ball-roller micro switch. When the filament runs out, the switch lever opens. Sailfish firmware:
http://jettyfirmware.yolasite.com/v76-v45.php Use of the P-stop function:
http://www.extrud3d.com/p-stop *A version with an oiler/cleaner is here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:297865

comments.text: Ingenious,very well done:-)
comments.author: technomastermind

comments.text: This will also work on a printer running Marlin firmware. All you need to do is set the switch to activate the M600 "Filament Change" code. I used this forum topic to get it working : http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,297350,381605
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text: Can you tell me the part number for the Omron ball roller switch that you used?
comments.author: ssignore

comments.text: Sure will, however at the moment I'm out of country on a business trip in PI.  I will answer as soon as I return/ get a chance.
comments.author: ssignore

comments.text: very nice idea!   I would suggest opening the connector holes a bit wider though, so that you can use a blade connector and not just push wire through the hole / solder it into place.   It looks like your switch is designed to do both, but Blade connectors are easier and removable (as compared to solder)
comments.author: bobnojio

description.text:
This is a mount for Gijs fanduct and other UM ducts.
Fanducts can heat up and sag into print jobs this helps avoid this by disassociating the parts. Video:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/scottmayson/7785855698/in/photostream
This fan mount will allow you to mount your fan away from the hot Ultimaker alloy plate and avoid sagging fans colliding with prints.

description.header: NOTE: Shorten the two inside screws in the Ply Bloks holding the Dia 6mm linear rods. Look at photo attached
description.text: Print and mount to your UM. Screw together Fan Holder and Fan Duct with plastic self tapping screws. Fasten with a Polyamide Zip Tie.

title: How to use octons construction game to illustrate your network connection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Octons construction game creating during MECSPE exposition in Parma by the participating companies of 3D printing area. Each octagonal piece was personalized with the company logo.
  • LAB: http://www.piulab.it/
    WASP: http://www.wasproject.it/w/
    BQ: http://www.bqreaders.com/gb/products/witbox.html
    KENT STRAPPER: http://www.kentstrapper.com/en
    3D SDM: http://www.sdm3d.it/
    ON OFF: http://officinaonoff.com/
    3DPR: http://www.3dpr.it/

How can be used octons game differently from playing?
To link your contacts and to create a network between them.
The connection is easy, visible and the desire to implement the network increases! You can print your logo high-relief or bas-relief as you like. We suggest to pierce it to obtain a better print and to join easier the pieces.

title: MendelMax Z endstop bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Z endstop switch holder for mendelmax.
Note: the STL and scad files as is are a little beefier than the prototype pictured here.  The prototype works fine, but better safe than sorry.
Edit: Changed to M2.5 screws.  They fit through the switch, just tight.

Print, place under the endstop plunger of your choosing. If you are using the official mendelmax xends, this works nicely: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26441 Currently using switch SS-3GL13P. If you want a different hole pattern, use the openscad file and change it. The file is parametric. Currently using switch SS-3GL13P. Attach switch with M2.5x14 bolts / nuts. There are nut traps in the back. The bracket screws into a t-slot nut with M5x10s.

description.text:
Run & Run is a practical wristband for runners. It is designed to insert a Cubot One mobile phone on one side and on the other side, a little case to carry your keys or money.   
The runner will be able to run without any trouble, because Run & Run is very light and comfortable.  
From now on there is no excuse to run!
It is done in SolidWorks and printed in a 3D printer

Hello!!
Here I publish my latest project, which is a tin where you can keep your pen and pensils. This tin is a bit special because it has different heights and you can see the pens easier than in the other usual tins.

It is a tool that is able to receive the bread crumbs. At the end of the cylinder it has a small bag  to attach. thanks to this you can receive bread crumbs there and when it es full you may remove the bag and put another one or you can empty the previous bag for reuse.

Hello!
This product is designed to keep your headphones without tangling between them. The design is very nice, this makes it more attractive to the eye!

Brushing kit is a practical gadget when you are brushing your teeth. You can keep together the toothbrush and the toothpaste. When the toothpaste is using up, you can go up the buffer stop in order to reach to the toothbrush. When you put the paste on the toothbrush you can rotate it so you don´t disturb.
With this device you can wrap the headphones comfortably
This is a cover to the phone that you can lead your money and your credit cards. And the most important thing is the phone.
I´ve made a photo frame for Valentine´s day.
This project is about a phone corver whose function is to facilitate the use of mobile while you drive.

remixed_from.author: Whatakuai
remixed_from.title: Armdudroid - Open Source Arduino and Android Controlled Robotic Arm

description.text:
An excavator that work on Bluetooth, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L5Wjv2P5PIM&feature=youtu.be the advantage of bluetooth is that you can make more like 6 channels,
I will post later everything to create and control rc models, it is a project that I'm booted and i have much to adapt,
work on an Arduino mini pro with HC-05, programmed to a
homemade android app Thanks thingsiverse and the people here a contribution of my project. I'll keep you informed, and will be posted more of my project stil in progresssss

It's actually quite easy to make this, and can actually be used for anything
only the program, settings (erdingers excavator :) is a puzzle,
it has cost me many days, but anyone can do it. the arduino sketch is from "Luis Manuel Rodriguez Picarzo" all credits to him, very nice sketch and very useful you can download my app for controler the servo arms, or you can design you own, the app is made in MIT App Inventor,
difficult, but manageable. if you sit down for a few days and well studied First thing, 'm just like everyone else, a hobby man, not an expert, have not a technical education,some programs I use for the first time,
first time that i post something, first time I explain something,
and and sorry for my bad English I will explain it as well as possible, also for the people who have never done this, and no idea have what they are doing.
I also started like that :) what do you need...... (normally a lot of time) Arduino mega, uno, ....
Arduino mini pro
Bluetooth device HC-05
Wire
LM317 Semiconductor
4x 1K resistor or 3x 1K and 2K, I had only one value
1x 220 Ohm
1x 47 Ohm
prototype board or the board that i made, All arduino and modules are 5v, and bought cheap on ebay, I've never had any problems with it. i do it step by step step 1. Connect hc-05 module to arduino
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u724cJnbwgM step 2. 6v to servo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=beVsVBo2zyE step 3. Upload sketch without usb

description.text: My kids made trees out of pipe cleaners, and they wanted a base that was a bit more stable. So I created this to look like roots.

2) Drill a hole in the top sized to fit the tree. (Default size can accommodate a hold up to about 6mm.) 
3) Insert tree.

author: Stmarthas

description.text:
The standard plastic printrbot base allows the z-motor to rock - this one doesn't. Optionally you can also use linear bearing clamps instead of zip-ties to hold the y-bearings in place.
My tested clamps have 4 holes for screws. I've added other two holes to this version. This is not because you need 6 but because you have the choice to use fewer - 2 may be enough but I haven't tested this.
The zip-tie slots are still there if you want them. Also the motor has been moved 0.5mm to match the spacing between the traveling Z-nut and smooth rod. And there is more.
There are holes you can tap for screws which lock the smooth rod.
There are also some mounting holes to screw the base down if you want too. The Y motor works fine the way it is but I'll probably add support because I can. Z+Y is working. There is a problem with spanner access. I've enlarged the hole in the CAD file but I'm not sure how well it will work. The test print is printed at .1mm and there is no real sign of ripple in it.

I wanted to print this in .2 layers but slic3r made a mess of the perimeters around the small holes. Tweaking the settings or using a different slicer might fix that but I just print it at .4mm The 2.6mm holes are meant to be tapped to M3. If you use the clamps and you have screws over the threaded rods they need to be short. If you over-tighten the clamp screws you will warp the flat part of the base. There is very little clearance between the clamp and the underside of my hotbed mount screw. I glued my Y limit switch in place and I found I no longer needed the Y adjuster screw. The motor bracing has a slot for the 5/16 nut but you generally have to screw that on as you slide the base/mount in place - if you slide the mount on without the nut you are unlikely to be able to get the nut on later. The Z+Y base.
Mine was printed in ABS at .3mm
Spanner access was a problem and the access is improved but may still be a problem. Make sure you slide it on with the 4 nuts in place and don't forget to include the ZEST part if you are using it here.
You should use my taller Y-bearing mounts. You don't want them to actually touch the motor so they are meant to be a fraction of a mm too short to touch. The Y belt needs to be raised. I raised mine 4mm but because my based printed out of square another couple of mm are needed.
I used a washer on either side of the bearings but other configurations may work. This is no problem if you use the standard Y clips but it is a CAD and print job for my belt posts.

comments.text: The smooth rod holes came out a little too large for me and the holes for the locking grub screws were a little too long for the M3 tap.  Thinking of inserting some hot glue into the big holes for that little bit of gap filling then the locking screws for alignment.
comments.author: Hoverhead

comments.text: My original kit bases had large holes as well - I used superglue to stop the movement.
comments.author: Hoverhead

comments.text: These are really nice.  I've considered doing something similar, but my method involves printing the "lead frame" as an object in it's own right and then having the pieces of "glass" as fitted objects. I think part of this is that I've made real stained glass and that's how my brain approaches it (and I see others have done the same on here).  Your idea is really neat though and you must get some interesting colour mixes.
